newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada dollar opens flat on quiet overseas trade.
newsitem.headline: Canada dollar opens flat on quiet overseas trade.

text.p: * Canada's dollar opened flat around C$1.3870 (US$0.7209) in light trading on Thursday after the currency was sidelined overnight in overseas markets, traders said. * They said they expected the Canada dollar to continue weakening, with a move to C$1.3900 (US$0.7194) possible ahead of Canadian employment data due to be released on Friday.
"I think a move to C$1.3900 (US$0.7194) is likely because the Canada (dollar) still looks weak," said a trader with a Canadian bank.
But some analysts said they expected the Canadian dollar to begin rebounding.
"The follow-through selling in Europe overnight was very light, and that suggests that the majority still want to buy the Canadian dollar back," said Rob Palombi, economist with MMS International.
"The Canadian jobs data out tomorrow morning could be a perfect opportunity for them to do that," Palombi added.
Overseas, the U.S. dollar took a backstage to the British pound as concerns that U.K. interest rates have peaked triggered a slump in the British currency.
Traders dumped pounds after the Bank of England said that interest rates were at levels consistent with Britain's inflation targets, a signal that British rates will not rise rise further.
"Sterling is back below the psychological three-mark level because the Bank (of England) has signalled that rates are on hold for now," said Nick Stamencovic, economist at DKB International.
On the crosses, the Canadian dollar dipped to 85.12 Japanese yen from Wednesday's 85.63 yen and fell to 1.3520 marks from Wednesday's 1.3563 marks.
((Paul Simao, Reuters Toronto Bureau (416) 941-8104) or email: paul.simao@reuters.com) (c) Reuters Limited 1997
